t:template.name: pieExamples
t:template.t:summary: Pie charts are useful for performing relative comparisons: how do the parts make up the whole? An alternative to pie is the donut chart.

t:template.name: barExamples
t:template.t:summary: Bar charts are used for plotting data which has discrete values. The lengths of the bars are proportional to the values that they represent.

t:template.name: boxExamples
t:template.t:summary: Boxplots are used to represent data distributions provided a five-number summary statistic.

t:template.name: dotExamples
t:template.t:summary: Dot charts consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale. It is a good alternative to the horizontal bar chart, in that it is less cluttered and redundant.

t:template.name: lineExamples
t:template.t:summary: Line charts are often used to visualize time series data.

t:template.name: stackedLineExamples
t:template.t:summary: Stacked line charts are line charts in which lines do not overlap because they are stacked at each point. This way, what you see is the trend of the contribution of each value over time.

t:template.name: stackedAreaExamples
t:template.t:summary: Stacked area charts are useful for displaying the trend of contribution of values of two or more variables to the total over categories or time.

t:template.name: heatGridExamples
t:template.t:summary: A heat-grid is a colored matrix that displays a two-dimensional data-set. The intensity or the color of each cell depends on the value that it represents.

t:template.name: waterfallExamples
t:template.t:summary:
Waterfall charts are an alternative to pie charts for displaying distributions. However when it's time to compare the size of categories and sub-categories, waterfall are the most convenient representation:
while in a pie-chart you would have to compare wedges at different angles, in a waterfall chart you just compare the size of bars as all bars are parallel to one another.
